  <div id="container">
    <div class="docs markdown"><div class="pilwrap" id="next-themes">
  <h1>
    <a href="#next-themes" name="next-themes" class="pilcrow"></a>
next-themes <img src="https://img.shields.io/bundlephobia/minzip/next-themes" alt="next-themes minzip package size"> <a href="https://www.npmjs.com/package/next-themes"><img src="https://img.shields.io/npm/v/next-themes.svg?colorB=green" alt="Version"></a>
  </h1>
</div>
<p>An abstraction for themes in your React app.</p>
<ul>
<li>✅ Perfect dark mode in 2 lines of code</li>
<li>✅ System setting with prefers-color-scheme</li>
<li>✅ Themed browser UI with color-scheme</li>
<li>✅ Support for Next.js 13 <code>appDir</code></li>
<li>✅ No flash on load (both SSR and SSG)</li>
<li>✅ Sync theme across tabs and windows</li>
<li>✅ Disable flashing when changing themes</li>
<li>✅ Force pages to specific themes</li>
<li>✅ Class or data attribute selector</li>
<li>✅ <code>useTheme</code> hook</li>
</ul>
<p>Check out the <a href="https://next-themes-example.vercel.app/">Live Example</a> to try it for yourself.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="install">
  <h2>
    <a href="#install" name="install" class="pilcrow"></a>
Install
  </h2>
</div>
<pre><code class="bash">$ npm install next-themes
<span class="hljs-comment"># or</span>
$ yarn add next-themes
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="use">
  <h2>
    <a href="#use" name="use" class="pilcrow"></a>
Use
  </h2>
</div>
<div class="pilwrap" id="with-pages">
  <h3>
    <a href="#with-pages" name="with-pages" class="pilcrow"></a>
With pages/
  </h3>
</div>
<p>You'll need a <a href="https://nextjs.org/docs/advanced-features/custom-app">Custom <code>App</code></a> to use next-themes. The simplest <code>_app</code> looks like this:</p>
<pre><code class="jsx"><span class="hljs-comment">// pages/_app.js</span>

<span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">function</span> <span class="hljs-title">MyApp</span>(<span class="hljs-params">{ Component, pageProps }</span>) </span>{
  <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> <span class="xml"><span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">Component</span> {<span class="hljs-attr">...pageProps</span>} /&gt;</span></span>
}

<span class="hljs-keyword">export</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">default</span> MyApp
</code></pre>
<p>Adding dark mode support takes 2 lines of code:</p>
<pre><code class="jsx"><span class="hljs-comment">// pages/_app.js</span>
<span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> { ThemeProvider } <span class="hljs-keyword">from</span> <span class="hljs-string">'next-themes'</span>

<span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">function</span> <span class="hljs-title">MyApp</span>(<span class="hljs-params">{ Component, pageProps }</span>) </span>{
  <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> (
    <span class="xml"><span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">ThemeProvider</span>&gt;</span>
      <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">Component</span> {<span class="hljs-attr">...pageProps</span>} /&gt;</span>
    <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;/<span class="hljs-name">ThemeProvider</span>&gt;</span></span>
  )
}

<span class="hljs-keyword">export</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">default</span> MyApp
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="with-app">
  <h3>
    <a href="#with-app" name="with-app" class="pilcrow"></a>
With app/
  </h3>
</div>
<p>You'll need to update your <code>app/layout.jsx</code> to use next-themes. The simplest <code>layout</code> looks like this:</p>
<pre><code class="jsx"><span class="hljs-comment">// app/layout.jsx</span>
<span class="hljs-keyword">export</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">default</span> <span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">function</span> <span class="hljs-title">Layout</span>(<span class="hljs-params">{ children }</span>) </span>{
  <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> (
    <span class="xml"><span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">html</span>&gt;</span>
      <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">head</span> /&gt;</span>
      <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">body</span>&gt;</span>{children}<span class="hljs-tag">&lt;/<span class="hljs-name">body</span>&gt;</span>
    <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;/<span class="hljs-name">html</span>&gt;</span></span>
  )
}
</code></pre>
<p>Adding dark mode support takes 2 lines of code:</p>
<pre><code class="jsx"><span class="hljs-comment">// app/layout.jsx</span>
<span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> { ThemeProvider } <span class="hljs-keyword">from</span> <span class="hljs-string">'next-themes'</span>

<span class="hljs-keyword">export</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">default</span> <span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">function</span> <span class="hljs-title">Layout</span>(<span class="hljs-params">{ children }</span>) </span>{
  <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> (
    <span class="xml"><span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">html</span> <span class="hljs-attr">suppressHydrationWarning</span>&gt;</span>
      <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">head</span> /&gt;</span>
      <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">body</span>&gt;</span>
        <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">ThemeProvider</span>&gt;</span>{children}<span class="hljs-tag">&lt;/<span class="hljs-name">ThemeProvider</span>&gt;</span>
      <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;/<span class="hljs-name">body</span>&gt;</span>
    <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;/<span class="hljs-name">html</span>&gt;</span></span>
  )
}
</code></pre>
<p>Note that <code>ThemeProvider</code> is a client component, not a server component.</p>
<blockquote>
<p><strong>Note!</strong> If you do not add <a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/dom-elements.html#suppresshydrationwarning:~:text=It%20only%20works%20one%20level%20deep">suppressHydrationWarning</a> to your <code>&lt;html&gt;</code> you will get warnings because <code>next-themes</code> updates that element. This property only applies one level deep, so it won't block hydration warnings on other elements.</p>
</blockquote>
<div class="pilwrap" id="html-and-css">
  <h3>
    <a href="#html-and-css" name="html-and-css" class="pilcrow"></a>
HTML &amp; CSS
  </h3>
</div>
<p>That's it, your Next.js app fully supports dark mode, including System preference with <code>prefers-color-scheme</code>. The theme is also immediately synced between tabs. By default, next-themes modifies the <code>data-theme</code> attribute on the <code>html</code> element, which you can easily use to style your app:</p>
<pre><code class="css"><span class="hljs-selector-pseudo">:root</span> {
  <span class="hljs-comment">/* Your default theme */</span>
  <span class="hljs-attribute">--background</span>: white;
  <span class="hljs-attribute">--foreground</span>: black;
}

<span class="hljs-selector-attr">[data-theme=<span class="hljs-string">'dark'</span>]</span> {
  <span class="hljs-attribute">--background</span>: black;
  <span class="hljs-attribute">--foreground</span>: white;
}
</code></pre>
<blockquote>
<p><strong>Note!</strong> If you set the attribute of your Theme Provider to class for Tailwind next-themes will modify the <code>class</code> attribute on the <code>html</code> element. See <a href="#with-tailwindcss.html">With TailwindCSS</a>.</p>
</blockquote>
<div class="pilwrap" id="usetheme">
  <h3>
    <a href="#usetheme" name="usetheme" class="pilcrow"></a>
useTheme
  </h3>
</div>
<p>Your UI will need to know the current theme and be able to change it. The <code>useTheme</code> hook provides theme information:</p>
<pre><code class="jsx"><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> { useTheme } <span class="hljs-keyword">from</span> <span class="hljs-string">'next-themes'</span>

<span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> ThemeChanger = <span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-params">()</span> =&gt;</span> {
  <span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> { theme, setTheme } = useTheme()

  <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> (
    <span class="xml"><span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">div</span>&gt;</span>
      The current theme is: {theme}
      <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">button</span> <span class="hljs-attr">onClick</span>=<span class="hljs-string">{()</span> =&gt;</span> setTheme('light')}&gt;Light Mode<span class="hljs-tag">&lt;/<span class="hljs-name">button</span>&gt;</span>
      <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">button</span> <span class="hljs-attr">onClick</span>=<span class="hljs-string">{()</span> =&gt;</span> setTheme('dark')}&gt;Dark Mode<span class="hljs-tag">&lt;/<span class="hljs-name">button</span>&gt;</span>
    <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;/<span class="hljs-name">div</span>&gt;</span></span>
  )
}
</code></pre>
<blockquote>
<p><strong>Warning!</strong> The above code is hydration <em>unsafe</em> and will throw a hydration mismatch warning when rendering with SSG or SSR. This is because we cannot know the <code>theme</code> on the server, so it will always be <code>undefined</code> until mounted on the client.</p>
<p>You should delay rendering any theme toggling UI until mounted on the client. See the <a href="#avoid-hydration-mismatch.html">example</a>.</p>
</blockquote>
<div class="pilwrap" id="api">
  <h2>
    <a href="#api" name="api" class="pilcrow"></a>
API
  </h2>
</div>
<p>Let's dig into the details.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="themeprovider">
  <h3>
    <a href="#themeprovider" name="themeprovider" class="pilcrow"></a>
ThemeProvider
  </h3>
</div>
<p>All your theme configuration is passed to ThemeProvider.</p>
<ul>
<li><code>storageKey = 'theme'</code>: Key used to store theme setting in localStorage</li>
<li><code>defaultTheme = 'system'</code>: Default theme name (for v0.0.12 and lower the default was <code>light</code>). If <code>enableSystem</code> is false, the default theme is <code>light</code></li>
<li><code>forcedTheme</code>: Forced theme name for the current page (does not modify saved theme settings)</li>
<li><code>enableSystem = true</code>: Whether to switch between <code>dark</code> and <code>light</code> based on <code>prefers-color-scheme</code></li>
<li><code>enableColorScheme = true</code>: Whether to indicate to browsers which color scheme is used (dark or light) for built-in UI like inputs and buttons</li>
<li><code>disableTransitionOnChange = false</code>: Optionally disable all CSS transitions when switching themes (<a href="#disable-transitions-on-theme-change.html">example</a>)</li>
<li><code>themes = ['light', 'dark']</code>: List of theme names</li>
<li><code>attribute = 'data-theme'</code>: HTML attribute modified based on the active theme
<ul>
<li>accepts <code>class</code> and <code>data-*</code> (meaning any data attribute, <code>data-mode</code>, <code>data-color</code>, etc.) (<a href="#class-instead-of-data-attribute.html">example</a>)</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><code>value</code>: Optional mapping of theme name to attribute value
<ul>
<li>value is an <code>object</code> where key is the theme name and value is the attribute value (<a href="#differing-dom-attribute-and-theme-name.html">example</a>)</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><code>nonce</code>: Optional nonce passed to the injected <code>script</code> tag, used to allow-list the next-themes script in your CSP</li>
<li><code>scriptProps</code>: Optional props to pass to the injected <code>script</code> tag (<a href="#using-with-cloudflare-rocket-loader.html">example</a>)</li>
</ul>
<div class="pilwrap" id="usetheme-1">
  <h3>
    <a href="#usetheme-1" name="usetheme-1" class="pilcrow"></a>
useTheme
  </h3>
</div>
<p>useTheme takes no parameters, but returns:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>theme</code>: Active theme name</li>
<li><code>setTheme(name)</code>: Function to update the theme. The API is identical to the <a href="https://react.dev/reference/react/useState#setstate">set function</a> returned by <code>useState</code>-hook. Pass the new theme value or use a callback to set the new theme based on the current theme.</li>
<li><code>forcedTheme</code>: Forced page theme or falsy. If <code>forcedTheme</code> is set, you should disable any theme switching UI</li>
<li><code>resolvedTheme</code>: If <code>enableSystem</code> is true and the active theme is &quot;system&quot;, this returns whether the system preference resolved to &quot;dark&quot; or &quot;light&quot;. Otherwise, identical to <code>theme</code></li>
<li><code>systemTheme</code>: If <code>enableSystem</code> is true, represents the System theme preference (&quot;dark&quot; or &quot;light&quot;), regardless what the active theme is</li>
<li><code>themes</code>: The list of themes passed to <code>ThemeProvider</code> (with &quot;system&quot; appended, if <code>enableSystem</code> is true)</li>
</ul>
<p>Not too bad, right? Let's see how to use these properties with examples:</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="examples">
  <h2>
    <a href="#examples" name="examples" class="pilcrow"></a>
Examples
  </h2>
</div>
<p>The <a href="https://next-themes-example.vercel.app/">Live Example</a> shows next-themes in action, with dark, light, system themes and pages with forced themes.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="use-system-preference-by-default">
  <h3>
    <a href="#use-system-preference-by-default" name="use-system-preference-by-default" class="pilcrow"></a>
Use System preference by default
  </h3>
</div>
<p>For versions above v0.0.12, the <code>defaultTheme</code> is automatically set to &quot;system&quot;, so to use System preference you can simply use:</p>
<pre><code class="jsx">&lt;ThemeProvider&gt;
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="ignore-system-preference">
  <h3>
    <a href="#ignore-system-preference" name="ignore-system-preference" class="pilcrow"></a>
Ignore System preference
  </h3>
</div>
<p>If you don't want a System theme, disable it via <code>enableSystem</code>:</p>
<pre><code class="jsx">&lt;ThemeProvider enableSystem={<span class="hljs-literal">false</span>}&gt;
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="class-instead-of-data-attribute">
  <h3>
    <a href="#class-instead-of-data-attribute" name="class-instead-of-data-attribute" class="pilcrow"></a>
Class instead of data attribute
  </h3>
</div>
<p>If your Next.js app uses a class to style the page based on the theme, change the attribute prop to <code>class</code>:</p>
<pre><code class="jsx">&lt;ThemeProvider attribute=<span class="hljs-string">"class"</span>&gt;
</code></pre>
<p>Now, setting the theme to &quot;dark&quot; will set <code>class=&quot;dark&quot;</code> on the <code>html</code> element.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="force-page-to-a-theme">
  <h3>
    <a href="#force-page-to-a-theme" name="force-page-to-a-theme" class="pilcrow"></a>
Force page to a theme
  </h3>
</div>
<p>Let's say your cool new marketing page is dark mode only. The page should always use the dark theme, and changing the theme should have no effect. To force a theme on your Next.js pages, simply set a variable on the page component:</p>
<pre><code class="js"><span class="hljs-comment">// pages/awesome-page.js</span>

<span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> Page = <span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-params">()</span> =&gt;</span> { ... }
Page.theme = <span class="hljs-string">'dark'</span>
<span class="hljs-keyword">export</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">default</span> Page
</code></pre>
<p>In your <code>_app</code>, read the variable and pass it to ThemeProvider:</p>
<pre><code class="jsx"><span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">function</span> <span class="hljs-title">MyApp</span>(<span class="hljs-params">{ Component, pageProps }</span>) </span>{
  <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> (
    <span class="xml"><span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">ThemeProvider</span> <span class="hljs-attr">forcedTheme</span>=<span class="hljs-string">{Component.theme</span> || <span class="hljs-attr">null</span>}&gt;</span>
      <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">Component</span> {<span class="hljs-attr">...pageProps</span>} /&gt;</span>
    <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;/<span class="hljs-name">ThemeProvider</span>&gt;</span></span>
  )
}
</code></pre>
<p>Done! Your page is always dark theme (regardless of user preference), and calling <code>setTheme</code> from <code>useTheme</code> is now a no-op. However, you should make sure to disable any of your UI that would normally change the theme:</p>
<pre><code class="js"><span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> { forcedTheme } = useTheme()

<span class="hljs-comment">// Theme is forced, we shouldn't allow user to change the theme</span>
<span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> disabled = !!forcedTheme
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="disable-transitions-on-theme-change">
  <h3>
    <a href="#disable-transitions-on-theme-change" name="disable-transitions-on-theme-change" class="pilcrow"></a>
Disable transitions on theme change
  </h3>
</div>
<p>I wrote about <a href="https://paco.sh/blog/disable-theme-transitions">this technique here</a>. We can forcefully disable all CSS transitions before the theme is changed, and re-enable them immediately afterwards. This ensures your UI with different transition durations won't feel inconsistent when changing the theme.</p>
<p>To enable this behavior, pass the <code>disableTransitionOnChange</code> prop:</p>
<pre><code class="jsx">&lt;ThemeProvider disableTransitionOnChange&gt;
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="differing-dom-attribute-and-theme-name">
  <h3>
    <a href="#differing-dom-attribute-and-theme-name" name="differing-dom-attribute-and-theme-name" class="pilcrow"></a>
Differing DOM attribute and theme name
  </h3>
</div>
<p>The name of the active theme is used as both the localStorage value and the value of the DOM attribute. If the theme name is &quot;pink&quot;, localStorage will contain <code>theme=pink</code> and the DOM will be <code>data-theme=&quot;pink&quot;</code>. You <strong>cannot</strong> modify the localStorage value, but you <strong>can</strong> modify the DOM value.</p>
<p>If we want the DOM to instead render <code>data-theme=&quot;my-pink-theme&quot;</code> when the theme is &quot;pink&quot;, pass the <code>value</code> prop:</p>
<pre><code class="jsx">&lt;ThemeProvider value={{ <span class="hljs-attr">pink</span>: <span class="hljs-string">'my-pink-theme'</span> }}&gt;
</code></pre>
<p>Done! To be extra clear, this affects only the DOM. Here's how all the values will look:</p>
<pre><code class="js"><span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> { theme } = useTheme()
<span class="hljs-comment">// =&gt; "pink"</span>

localStorage.getItem(<span class="hljs-string">'theme'</span>)
<span class="hljs-comment">// =&gt; "pink"</span>

<span class="hljs-built_in">document</span>.documentElement.getAttribute(<span class="hljs-string">'data-theme'</span>)
<span class="hljs-comment">// =&gt; "my-pink-theme"</span>
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="using-with-cloudflare-rocket-loader">
  <h3>
    <a href="#using-with-cloudflare-rocket-loader" name="using-with-cloudflare-rocket-loader" class="pilcrow"></a>
Using with Cloudflare Rocket Loader
  </h3>
</div>
<p><a href="https://developers.cloudflare.com/fundamentals/speed/rocket-loader/">Rocket Loader</a> is a Cloudflare optimization that defers the loading of inline and external scripts to prioritize the website content. Since next-themes relies on a script injection to avoid screen flashing on page load, Rocket Loader breaks this functionality. Individual scripts <a href="https://developers.cloudflare.com/fundamentals/speed/rocket-loader/ignore-javascripts/">can be ignored</a> by adding the <code>data-cfasync=&quot;false&quot;</code> attribute to the script tag:</p>
<pre><code class="jsx">&lt;ThemeProvider scriptProps={{ <span class="hljs-string">'data-cfasync'</span>: <span class="hljs-string">'false'</span> }}&gt;
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="more-than-light-and-dark-mode">
  <h3>
    <a href="#more-than-light-and-dark-mode" name="more-than-light-and-dark-mode" class="pilcrow"></a>
More than light and dark mode
  </h3>
</div>
<p>next-themes is designed to support any number of themes! Simply pass a list of themes:</p>
<pre><code class="jsx">&lt;ThemeProvider themes={[<span class="hljs-string">'pink'</span>, <span class="hljs-string">'red'</span>, <span class="hljs-string">'blue'</span>]}&gt;
</code></pre>
<blockquote>
<p><strong>Note!</strong> When you pass <code>themes</code>, the default set of themes (&quot;light&quot; and &quot;dark&quot;) are overridden. Make sure you include those if you still want your light and dark themes:</p>
</blockquote>
<pre><code class="jsx">&lt;ThemeProvider themes={[<span class="hljs-string">'pink'</span>, <span class="hljs-string">'red'</span>, <span class="hljs-string">'blue'</span>, <span class="hljs-string">'light'</span>, <span class="hljs-string">'dark'</span>]}&gt;
</code></pre>
<p>For an example on how to use this, check out the <a href="./examples/multi-theme/README.md.html">multi-theme example</a></p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="without-css-variables">
  <h3>
    <a href="#without-css-variables" name="without-css-variables" class="pilcrow"></a>
Without CSS variables
  </h3>
</div>
<p>This library does not rely on your theme styling using CSS variables. You can hard-code the values in your CSS, and everything will work as expected (without any flashing):</p>
<pre><code class="css"><span class="hljs-selector-tag">html</span>,
<span class="hljs-selector-tag">body</span> {
  <span class="hljs-attribute">color</span>: <span class="hljs-number">#000</span>;
  <span class="hljs-attribute">background</span>: <span class="hljs-number">#fff</span>;
}

<span class="hljs-selector-attr">[data-theme=<span class="hljs-string">'dark'</span>]</span>,
<span class="hljs-selector-attr">[data-theme=<span class="hljs-string">'dark'</span>]</span> <span class="hljs-selector-tag">body</span> {
  <span class="hljs-attribute">color</span>: <span class="hljs-number">#fff</span>;
  <span class="hljs-attribute">background</span>: <span class="hljs-number">#000</span>;
}
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="with-styled-components-and-any-css-in-js">
  <h3>
    <a href="#with-styled-components-and-any-css-in-js" name="with-styled-components-and-any-css-in-js" class="pilcrow"></a>
With Styled Components and any CSS-in-JS
  </h3>
</div>
<p>Next Themes is completely CSS independent, it will work with any library. For example, with Styled Components you just need to <code>createGlobalStyle</code> in your custom App:</p>
<pre><code class="jsx"><span class="hljs-comment">// pages/_app.js</span>
<span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> { createGlobalStyle } <span class="hljs-keyword">from</span> <span class="hljs-string">'styled-components'</span>
<span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> { ThemeProvider } <span class="hljs-keyword">from</span> <span class="hljs-string">'next-themes'</span>

<span class="hljs-comment">// Your themeing variables</span>
<span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> GlobalStyle = createGlobalStyle<span class="hljs-string">`
  :root {
    --fg: #000;
    --bg: #fff;
  }

  [data-theme="dark"] {
    --fg: #fff;
    --bg: #000;
  }
`</span>

<span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">function</span> <span class="hljs-title">MyApp</span>(<span class="hljs-params">{ Component, pageProps }</span>) </span>{
  <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> (
    <span class="xml"><span class="hljs-tag">&lt;&gt;</span>
      <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">GlobalStyle</span> /&gt;</span>
      <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">ThemeProvider</span>&gt;</span>
        <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">Component</span> {<span class="hljs-attr">...pageProps</span>} /&gt;</span>
      <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;/<span class="hljs-name">ThemeProvider</span>&gt;</span>
    <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;/&gt;</span></span>
  )
}
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="avoid-hydration-mismatch">
  <h3>
    <a href="#avoid-hydration-mismatch" name="avoid-hydration-mismatch" class="pilcrow"></a>
Avoid Hydration Mismatch
  </h3>
</div>
<p>Because we cannot know the <code>theme</code> on the server, many of the values returned from <code>useTheme</code> will be <code>undefined</code> until mounted on the client. This means if you try to render UI based on the current theme before mounting on the client, you will see a hydration mismatch error.</p>
<p>The following code sample is <strong>unsafe</strong>:</p>
<pre><code class="jsx"><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> { useTheme } <span class="hljs-keyword">from</span> <span class="hljs-string">'next-themes'</span>

<span class="hljs-comment">// Do NOT use this! It will throw a hydration mismatch error.</span>
<span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> ThemeSwitch = <span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-params">()</span> =&gt;</span> {
  <span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> { theme, setTheme } = useTheme()

  <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> (
    <span class="xml"><span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">select</span> <span class="hljs-attr">value</span>=<span class="hljs-string">{theme}</span> <span class="hljs-attr">onChange</span>=<span class="hljs-string">{e</span> =&gt;</span> setTheme(e.target.value)}&gt;
      <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">option</span> <span class="hljs-attr">value</span>=<span class="hljs-string">"system"</span>&gt;</span>System<span class="hljs-tag">&lt;/<span class="hljs-name">option</span>&gt;</span>
      <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">option</span> <span class="hljs-attr">value</span>=<span class="hljs-string">"dark"</span>&gt;</span>Dark<span class="hljs-tag">&lt;/<span class="hljs-name">option</span>&gt;</span>
      <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">option</span> <span class="hljs-attr">value</span>=<span class="hljs-string">"light"</span>&gt;</span>Light<span class="hljs-tag">&lt;/<span class="hljs-name">option</span>&gt;</span>
    <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;/<span class="hljs-name">select</span>&gt;</span></span>
  )
}

<span class="hljs-keyword">export</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">default</span> ThemeSwitch
</code></pre>
<p>To fix this, make sure you only render UI that uses the current theme when the page is mounted on the client:</p>
<pre><code class="jsx"><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> { useState, useEffect } <span class="hljs-keyword">from</span> <span class="hljs-string">'react'</span>
<span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> { useTheme } <span class="hljs-keyword">from</span> <span class="hljs-string">'next-themes'</span>

<span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> ThemeSwitch = <span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-params">()</span> =&gt;</span> {
  <span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> [mounted, setMounted] = useState(<span class="hljs-literal">false</span>)
  <span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> { theme, setTheme } = useTheme()

  <span class="hljs-comment">// useEffect only runs on the client, so now we can safely show the UI</span>
  useEffect(<span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-params">()</span> =&gt;</span> {
    setMounted(<span class="hljs-literal">true</span>)
  }, [])

  <span class="hljs-keyword">if</span> (!mounted) {
    <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> <span class="hljs-literal">null</span>
  }

  <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> (
    <span class="xml"><span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">select</span> <span class="hljs-attr">value</span>=<span class="hljs-string">{theme}</span> <span class="hljs-attr">onChange</span>=<span class="hljs-string">{e</span> =&gt;</span> setTheme(e.target.value)}&gt;
      <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">option</span> <span class="hljs-attr">value</span>=<span class="hljs-string">"system"</span>&gt;</span>System<span class="hljs-tag">&lt;/<span class="hljs-name">option</span>&gt;</span>
      <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">option</span> <span class="hljs-attr">value</span>=<span class="hljs-string">"dark"</span>&gt;</span>Dark<span class="hljs-tag">&lt;/<span class="hljs-name">option</span>&gt;</span>
      <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">option</span> <span class="hljs-attr">value</span>=<span class="hljs-string">"light"</span>&gt;</span>Light<span class="hljs-tag">&lt;/<span class="hljs-name">option</span>&gt;</span>
    <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;/<span class="hljs-name">select</span>&gt;</span></span>
  )
}

<span class="hljs-keyword">export</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">default</span> ThemeSwitch
</code></pre>
<p>Alternatively, you could lazy load the component on the client side. The following example uses <code>next/dynamic</code> but you could also use <code>React.lazy</code>:</p>
<pre><code class="js"><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> dynamic <span class="hljs-keyword">from</span> <span class="hljs-string">'next/dynamic'</span>

<span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> ThemeSwitch = dynamic(<span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-params">()</span> =&gt;</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">import</span>(<span class="hljs-string">'./ThemeSwitch'</span>), { <span class="hljs-attr">ssr</span>: <span class="hljs-literal">false</span> })

<span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> ThemePage = <span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-params">()</span> =&gt;</span> {
  <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> (
    <span class="xml"><span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">div</span>&gt;</span>
      <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">ThemeSwitch</span> /&gt;</span>
    <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;/<span class="hljs-name">div</span>&gt;</span></span>
  )
}

<span class="hljs-keyword">export</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">default</span> ThemePage
</code></pre>
<p>To avoid <a href="https://web.dev/cls/">Layout Shift</a>, consider rendering a skeleton/placeholder until mounted on the client side.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="images">
  <h4>
    <a href="#images" name="images" class="pilcrow"></a>
Images
  </h4>
</div>
<p>Showing different images based on the current theme also suffers from the hydration mismatch problem. With <a href="https://nextjs.org/docs/basic-features/image-optimization"><code>next/image</code></a> you can use an empty image until the theme is resolved:</p>
<pre><code class="jsx"><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> Image <span class="hljs-keyword">from</span> <span class="hljs-string">'next/image'</span>
<span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> { useTheme } <span class="hljs-keyword">from</span> <span class="hljs-string">'next-themes'</span>

<span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">function</span> <span class="hljs-title">ThemedImage</span>(<span class="hljs-params"></span>) </span>{
  <span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> { resolvedTheme } = useTheme()
  <span class="hljs-keyword">let</span> src

  <span class="hljs-keyword">switch</span> (resolvedTheme) {
    <span class="hljs-keyword">case</span> <span class="hljs-string">'light'</span>:
      src = <span class="hljs-string">'/light.png'</span>
      <span class="hljs-keyword">break</span>
    <span class="hljs-keyword">case</span> <span class="hljs-string">'dark'</span>:
      src = <span class="hljs-string">'/dark.png'</span>
      <span class="hljs-keyword">break</span>
    <span class="hljs-attr">default</span>:
      src = <span class="hljs-string">'data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7'</span>
      <span class="hljs-keyword">break</span>
  }

  <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> <span class="xml"><span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">Image</span> <span class="hljs-attr">src</span>=<span class="hljs-string">{src}</span> <span class="hljs-attr">width</span>=<span class="hljs-string">{400}</span> <span class="hljs-attr">height</span>=<span class="hljs-string">{400}</span> /&gt;</span></span>
}

<span class="hljs-keyword">export</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">default</span> ThemedImage
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="css">
  <h4>
    <a href="#css" name="css" class="pilcrow"></a>
CSS
  </h4>
</div>
<p>You can also use CSS to hide or show content based on the current theme. To avoid the hydration mismatch, you'll need to render <em>both</em> versions of the UI, with CSS hiding the unused version. For example:</p>
<pre><code class="jsx"><span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">function</span> <span class="hljs-title">ThemedImage</span>(<span class="hljs-params"></span>) </span>{
  <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> (
    <span class="xml"><span class="hljs-tag">&lt;&gt;</span>
      {/* When the theme is dark, hide this div */}
      <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">div</span> <span class="hljs-attr">data-hide-on-theme</span>=<span class="hljs-string">"dark"</span>&gt;</span>
        <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">Image</span> <span class="hljs-attr">src</span>=<span class="hljs-string">"light.png"</span> <span class="hljs-attr">width</span>=<span class="hljs-string">{400}</span> <span class="hljs-attr">height</span>=<span class="hljs-string">{400}</span> /&gt;</span>
      <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;/<span class="hljs-name">div</span>&gt;</span>

      {/* When the theme is light, hide this div */}
      <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">div</span> <span class="hljs-attr">data-hide-on-theme</span>=<span class="hljs-string">"light"</span>&gt;</span>
        <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;<span class="hljs-name">Image</span> <span class="hljs-attr">src</span>=<span class="hljs-string">"dark.png"</span> <span class="hljs-attr">width</span>=<span class="hljs-string">{400}</span> <span class="hljs-attr">height</span>=<span class="hljs-string">{400}</span> /&gt;</span>
      <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;/<span class="hljs-name">div</span>&gt;</span>
    <span class="hljs-tag">&lt;/&gt;</span></span>
  )
}

<span class="hljs-keyword">export</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">default</span> ThemedImage
</code></pre>
<pre><code class="css"><span class="hljs-selector-attr">[data-theme=<span class="hljs-string">'dark'</span>]</span> <span class="hljs-selector-attr">[data-hide-on-theme=<span class="hljs-string">'dark'</span>]</span>,
<span class="hljs-selector-attr">[data-theme=<span class="hljs-string">'light'</span>]</span> <span class="hljs-selector-attr">[data-hide-on-theme=<span class="hljs-string">'light'</span>]</span> {
  <span class="hljs-attribute">display</span>: none;
}
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="with-tailwindcss">
  <h3>
    <a href="#with-tailwindcss" name="with-tailwindcss" class="pilcrow"></a>
With TailwindCSS
  </h3>
</div>
<p><a href="https://next-themes-tailwind.vercel.app">Visit the live example</a> • <a href="https://github.com/pacocoursey/next-themes/tree/master/examples/tailwind">View the example source code</a></p>
<blockquote>
<p>NOTE! Tailwind only supports dark mode in version &gt;2.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>In your <code>tailwind.config.js</code>, set the dark mode property to <code>selector</code>:</p>
<pre><code class="js"><span class="hljs-comment">// tailwind.config.js</span>
<span class="hljs-built_in">module</span>.exports = {
  <span class="hljs-attr">darkMode</span>: <span class="hljs-string">'selector'</span>
}
</code></pre>
<p><em>Note: If you are using an older version of tailwindcss &lt; 3.4.1 use <code>'class'</code> instead of <code>'selector'</code></em></p>
<p>Set the attribute for your Theme Provider to class:</p>
<pre><code class="tsx">// pages/_app.tsx
&lt;ThemeProvider attribute=&quot;class&quot;&gt;
</code></pre>
<p>If you're using the value prop to specify different attribute values, make sure your dark theme explicitly uses the &quot;dark&quot; value, as required by Tailwind.</p>
<p>That's it! Now you can use dark-mode specific classes:</p>
<pre><code class="tsx">&lt;h1 className=&quot;text-black dark:text-white&quot;&gt;
</code></pre>
<div class="pilwrap" id="using-a-custom-selector-tailwindcss-greater-3.4.1">
  <h4>
    <a href="#using-a-custom-selector-tailwindcss-greater-3.4.1" name="using-a-custom-selector-tailwindcss-greater-3.4.1" class="pilcrow"></a>
Using a custom selector (tailwindcss &gt; 3.4.1)
  </h4>
</div>
<p>Tailwind also allows you to use a <a href="https://tailwindcss.com/docs/dark-mode#customizing-the-selector">custom selector</a> for dark-mode as of v3.4.1.</p>
<p>In that case, your <code>tailwind.config.js</code> would look like this:</p>
<pre><code class="js"><span class="hljs-comment">// tailwind.config.js</span>
<span class="hljs-built_in">module</span>.exports = {
  <span class="hljs-comment">// data-mode is used as an example, next-themes supports using any data attribute</span>
  <span class="hljs-attr">darkMode</span>: [<span class="hljs-string">'selector'</span>, <span class="hljs-string">'[data-mode="dark"]'</span>]
  …
}
</code></pre>
<p>Now set the attribute for your ThemeProvider to <code>data-mode</code>:</p>
<pre><code class="tsx">// pages/_app.tsx
&lt;ThemeProvider attribute=&quot;data-mode&quot;&gt;
</code></pre>
<p>With this setup, you can now use Tailwind's dark mode classes, as in the previous example:</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="discussion">
  <h2>
    <a href="#discussion" name="discussion" class="pilcrow"></a>
Discussion
  </h2>
</div>
<div class="pilwrap" id="the-flash">
  <h3>
    <a href="#the-flash" name="the-flash" class="pilcrow"></a>
The Flash
  </h3>
</div>
<p>ThemeProvider automatically injects a script into <code>next/head</code> to update the <code>html</code> element with the correct attributes before the rest of your page loads. This means the page will not flash under any circumstances, including forced themes, system theme, multiple themes, and incognito. No <code>noflash.js</code> required.</p>
<div class="pilwrap" id="faq">
  <h2>
    <a href="#faq" name="faq" class="pilcrow"></a>
FAQ
  </h2>
</div>
<hr>
<p><strong>Why is my page still flashing?</strong></p>
<p>In Next.js dev mode, the page may still flash. When you build your app in production mode, there will be no flashing.</p>
<hr>
<p><strong>Why do I get server/client mismatch error?</strong></p>
<p>When using <code>useTheme</code>, you will use see a hydration mismatch error when rendering UI that relies on the current theme. This is because many of the values returned by <code>useTheme</code> are undefined on the server, since we can't read <code>localStorage</code> until mounting on the client. See the <a href="#avoid-hydration-mismatch.html">example</a> for how to fix this error.</p>
<hr>
<p><strong>Do I need to use CSS variables with this library?</strong></p>
<p>Nope. See the <a href="#without-css-variables.html">example</a>.</p>
<hr>
<p><strong>Can I set the class or data attribute on the body or another element?</strong></p>
<p>Nope. If you have a good reason for supporting this feature, please open an issue.</p>
<hr>
<p><strong>Can I use this package with Gatsby or CRA?</strong></p>
<p>Yes, starting from the 0.3.0 version.</p>
<hr>
<p><strong>Is the injected script minified?</strong></p>
<p>Yes.</p>
<hr>
<p><strong>Why is <code>resolvedTheme</code> necessary?</strong></p>
<p>When supporting the System theme preference, you want to make sure that's reflected in your UI. This means your buttons, selects, dropdowns, or whatever you use to indicate the current theme should say &quot;System&quot; when the System theme preference is active.</p>
<p>If we didn't distinguish between <code>theme</code> and <code>resolvedTheme</code>, the UI would show &quot;Dark&quot; or &quot;Light&quot;, when it should really be &quot;System&quot;.</p>
<p><code>resolvedTheme</code> is then useful for modifying behavior or styles at runtime:</p>
<pre><code class="jsx"><span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> { resolvedTheme } = useTheme()

&lt;div style={{ <span class="hljs-attr">color</span>: resolvedTheme === <span class="hljs-string">'dark'</span> ? <span class="hljs-string">'white'</span> : <span class="hljs-string">'black'</span> }}&gt;
</code></pre>
<p>If we didn't have <code>resolvedTheme</code> and only used <code>theme</code>, you'd lose information about the state of your UI (you would only know the theme is &quot;system&quot;, and not what it resolved to).</p>
</div>
  </div>
</body>
</html>
